Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Story: I glanced at the calendar on the fridge, the bold red circle around today’s date reminding me of the family gathering I’d promised my daughter I wouldn’t miss. My grandson had been talking all week about showing me his new model train set, and I could already picture his eager face waiting at the door. Just as I was about to grab my coat, my phone buzzed. It was Mark, my old friend from college. “Hey, sorry to bother you, but I’m in a bit of a jam. I can’t make sense of these furniture instructions—could you hop on a quick video call?” I could hear the frustration in his voice, and I knew he didn’t have anyone else nearby to help. My heart tugged in two directions: the warmth of family, the laughter and stories I’d miss if I was late, and the loyalty I felt toward a friend who needed me. I stood in the hallway, coat in hand, phone in the other, feeling the weight of both promises pressing down on me, unsure which path to take.
